examples.en: Did you already see Tofugu's public, financial announcement?
examples.ja: トーフグの決算公告、もう見ましたか。

examples.en: Tofugu decided to put up an important public notice about Koichi in an official telegram.
examples.ja: トーフグは、日本政府の官報にコウイチについての重大な公告をのせることにしました。

examples.en: There is a law in Japan called the Electronic Public Notice Regulation. Do you have anything like that in your country?
examples.ja: 日本には、電子公告規則という法律がありますが、あなたの国はどうですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>announcement</kanji> is a <vocabulary>public notice</vocabulary>.

公告 looks and sounds a lot like 広告, but the meanings are different. You might remember 広告 is for advertisements, but 公告 here is for the kind of official statements that companies or governments put out for the public, especially shareholders, creditors, or other stakeholders.

You can remember 公告 is a public notice because the kanji for "public" is 公, and it's not covered by a canopy like the other one. It's uncovered, all out in the open for everyone to see — public!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This music is very rhythmic.
examples.ja: この音楽はとても律動的ですね。

examples.en: Out of the Tofugu team, Kanae was doing the radio gymnastics the most rhythmically.
examples.ja: トーフグチームの中で、一番律動的にラジオ体操をしていたのは、カナエです。

examples.en: This morning, I saw a lot of rabbits jumping rhythmically in my garden.
examples.ja: 今朝、たくさんのウサギが庭で律動的に飛び跳ねているのを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>law</kanji> of <kanji>move</kanji>ment is governed by <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary>. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm. 

Note that リズム is a much more common word to use for "rhythm," but you may see the kanji version sometimes in formal writing. One thing you will see more often is 律動的 which means "rhythmic."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We're poor, but we intend to save for our child's education somehow.
examples.ja: 貧乏ですが、何とか子供の学資は貯えるつもりです。

examples.en: We've been setting aside food and water in the warehouse in case an earthquake happens.
examples.ja: 地震が起きた時のために、倉庫に食料品や水を貯えてるんです。

examples.en: We need to save up some funds before we can start a big business.
examples.ja: 大きなビジネスを始める前に、元手を貯える必要がある。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Notice how it shares its reading with 蓄える and its kanji with 貯める? It also has a similar meaning — <vocabulary>to set aside</vocabulary>.

Note that 貯える is less common in modern writing, and often feels a little old-fashioned. But you might still see it in contexts where it means <vocabulary>to store up</vocabulary> food and supplies for future needs (like 蓄える) or <vocabulary>to save up</vocabulary> money (like 貯める).
reading_mnemonic:
This shares a reading with 蓄える, which makes sense since their meanings are so similar! Here's a mnemonic just in case you don't remember the reading:

You need <vocabulary>to set aside</vocabulary> some things, so you <reading>take one</reading> (たくわ) and set it aside, then take one more and set it aside again. Repeat this process <vocabulary>to store up</vocabulary> lots of things over time.

examples.en: I have to wake up early tomorrow morning to practice for the athletic meet’s mock cavalry battle.
examples.ja: 運動会の騎馬戦の練習があるので、明日は早起きしなくてはいけません。

examples.en: "I saw a police officer riding a horse earlier!" "Oh, you mean mounted police. Do you not have them in Japan?”
examples.ja: 「さっき馬に乗った警察官を見たよ！」「ああ、騎馬警官って言うんだよ。日本にはいないの？」

examples.en: The people of Mongolia and Kazakhstan are known as equestrian peoples.
examples.ja: モンゴルやカザフスタンの人々は、騎馬民族として知られている。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>horse</kanji> is what you need for <vocabulary>riding a horse</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word and it’s typically used at the beginning of compounds where you'll see it translated as things like <vocabulary>mounted</vocabulary>, as in "mounted police," or <vocabulary>equestrian</vocabulary>, as in “equestrian peoples.” It's working like an adjective there, but it's still a noun in Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That photo of the cavalries reminds me a bit of my youth.
examples.ja: その騎兵の写真、なんだか若かりし頃を思い出すな。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>soldier</kanji> is a member of the <vocabulary>cavalry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Let's ask Kuwabara-san!
examples.ja: 桑原さんに聞いてみましょう！

examples.en: Wha-, how scary! Knock on wood that that won’t happen!
examples.ja: えっ、こわっ！桑原桑原！

examples.en: People started calling this place "Kuwabara" because there used to be a lot of mulberry fields here.
examples.ja: かつては桑畑がたくさんあったため、この場所は「桑原」と呼ばれるようになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary>.

Based on an old belief that lightning does not strike mulberry fields, 桑原 (often recited twice, as in "桑原桑原") can also be used as a charm to ward off undesirable events, though it's pretty old-fashioned.

Apart from that use, 桑原 now mainly refers to the family name <vocabulary>Kuwabara</vocabulary>, like one of the main protagonists of the anime and manga series 幽遊白書.
reading_mnemonic:
These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead:

You know you're in a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary> when you see a bunch of capy<reading>bara</reading>s (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!

examples.en: Imagine that the glittering stars are all melting into the night sky.
examples.ja: あの光り輝く星々が、夜空に溶けるのを想像してみてください。

meaning_mnemonic: 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける <vocabulary>to melt</vocabulary> (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 溶かす.

examples.en: He’s such a cunning guy and he’s very good at feigning innocence too.
examples.ja: あいつは悪賢い男で、猫かぶりが大のお得意なんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone who is <kanji>bad</kanji> but also <kanji>clever</kanji> (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as <vocabulary>devious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>cunning</vocabulary>, or other things.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: I was disoriented by the radiance of the diamond.
examples.ja: 私はそのダイヤモンドの輝きに目がくらんでしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be <vocabulary>radiance</vocabulary>. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 輝く.

examples.en: I’m getting hungry. I’m looking forward to having crab for dinner.
examples.ja: お腹がすいてきた。晩ご飯の蟹が楽しみだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, <kanji>crab</kanji>. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

examples.en: This alligator statue is in the way.
examples.ja: この鰐の置物、邪魔なんだけど。

examples.en: You can handwrite the kanji for WaniKani without looking at anything? That's amazing!
examples.ja: 鰐蟹って漢字、何も見ずに手書きで書けるの？すごいね！

examples.en: I have a stuffed alligator displayed in my room.
examples.ja: 鰐の剥製が部屋に飾ってあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The great <kanji>alligator</kanji>! This can mean both <vocabulary>alligator</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crocodile</vocabulary>, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.

examples.en: "This girl is so annoying." "Yo, don't worry about it."
examples.ja: 「この女マジ鬱陶しいんだけど。」「よー。気にすんなって。」

examples.en: The gloomy rain has been persisting, hasn't it?
examples.ja: 鬱陶しい雨が続いてるね。

examples.en: Yeah, it's been depressing with the constant overcast skies.
examples.ja: うん。ずっと曇り空ばかりで鬱陶しいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Gloom</kanji> <kanji>pottery</kanji> is... well, it's <vocabulary>gloomy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>depressing</vocabulary>!

This word can also mean <vocabulary>annoying</vocabulary>. If something or someone always makes you feel gloomy, you'll probably think it's annoying, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.

examples.en: My sister and I climbed up to the peak of Mt. Fuji, rising up above the clouds.
examples.ja: 妹と私は、雲の上にそびえる富士山の峰に登頂しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ridge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Look up at the <vocabulary>summit</vocabulary>. It's such a <reading>mean</reading> (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

examples.en: Today’s mountain range cleared up nicely and the view is great.
examples.ja: 今日の連峰はよく晴れていて見晴らしがいいです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Take along</kanji> this <kanji>summit</kanji> and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a <vocabulary>mountain range</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: It’s too good to be true. What are you scheming?
examples.ja: 話が巧すぎるぜ。何か企んでるだろ？

meaning_mnemonic: You're so <kanji>adept</kanji>! That makes you <vocabulary>adept</vocabulary> at that thing. <vocabulary>Skillful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> are other ways to do it too.
reading_mnemonic: Remember 旨い, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.

examples.en: The evil witch cleverly pretended to approach the girl by mere chance.
examples.ja: ある邪悪な魔法使いが、巧妙に偶然を装って女性に近づきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that is <kanji>adept</kanji> but <kanji>peculiar</kanji> in how adept it is would have to be something truly <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ingenious</vocabulary>. Like a clever scam or trick.

巧妙 is typically used to describe deceptive actions, techniques, or methods that are not only <vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary> but also somewhat sly or crafty. It indicates a level of sophistication, often involving clever scheming or manipulation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Why aren’t you coming to your mom’s funeral?" "’Cause I caught a cold."
examples.ja: 「なんで母親の葬式に来ないの？」「風邪ひいてるからだよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wind</kanji> that is <kanji>wicked</kanji> comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

examples.en: Don’t stand in my way. I can do it by myself!
examples.ja: 私の邪魔をするな。一人で出来るよ！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wicked</kanji> <kanji>devil</kanji>! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a <vocabulary>hindrance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intrusion</vocabulary>. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: God saw through my wicked heart.
examples.ja: 神様は私の邪な心を見透かしていらっしゃったんだわ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being <vocabulary>wicked</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Evil</vocabulary>, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the <reading>横島</reading> (よこしま).

examples.en: These wooden clogs come in two colors.
examples.ja: こちらの下駄は二色のお色をご用意しております。

meaning_mnemonic: Look <kanji>below</kanji> you. These things carry your <kanji>burdensome</kanji> weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically <vocabulary>geta</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Japanese wooden clogs</vocabulary>. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

examples.en: You absolutely cannot go on a trip with a boy!
examples.ja: 男の子と旅行に行くのは、絶対に駄目ですからね！

meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>burdensome</kanji> to the <kanji>eye</kanji> (when you look at it), you know that that thing is <vocabulary>not good</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hopeless</vocabulary>. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean <vocabulary>not allowed</vocabulary>. Parents say this to their kids all the time.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Just saying it is useless. Fugu never listens to advice.
examples.ja: 言うだけ無駄だよ。フグは決して忠告には耳を貸さないんだから。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Nothing</kanji> but <kanji>burdensome</kanji>. That's all you get out of doing this task. The <vocabulary>futility</vocabulary> of it is ridiculous. The <vocabulary>uselessness</vocabulary> is huge.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She suddenly asked me to repair her car.
examples.ja: 彼女、唐突に車の修理をしてほしいって俺に頼んできたんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>stab</kanji> is <vocabulary>abrupt</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unexpected</vocabulary>. Quick, dodge!!

唐突 describes sudden actions or events that catch people off guard.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you know how much longer we will be in this courtroom?
examples.ja: あとどれくらい私達がこの法廷にいることになるか分かりますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>law</kanji> <kanji>courts</kanji> are the <vocabulary>court</vocabulary>s you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a <vocabulary>courtroom</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A chest cold is going around the Imperial Court.
examples.ja: 宮廷では咳風邪が流行っています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji> <kanji>courts</kanji> are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the <vocabulary>imperial court</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Royal court</vocabulary> will do as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how <reading>cu</reading>te (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.

examples.en: He laid face up and looked through all the names in the register.
examples.ja: 彼は仰向けに寝転がって、名簿の全ての名前に目を通した。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>name</kanji> <kanji>record book</kanji> is a book that contains names. That is a <vocabulary>register of names</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>list of names</vocabulary>. Is your name on the list?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I didn’t think of the idea to burn the account book.
examples.ja: 帳簿を燃やしてしまうという考えは思いつきませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>notebook</kanji> that is also a <kanji>record book</kanji> is an <vocabulary>account book</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>register</vocabulary>, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I came home without attending the awards ceremony.
examples.ja: 表彰式には出席せずに帰ってきてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: You want people to <kanji>express</kanji> how they feel about you in a <kanji>clear</kanji> manner, so you demand they give you <vocabulary>public acknowledgement</vocabulary>. You want clear, concise <vocabulary>public recognition</vocabulary> for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are various styles in manga.
examples.ja: 漫画には色々な形式があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Comic</kanji> <kanji>drawing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>manga</vocabulary>, a.k.a. <vocabulary>Japanese comics</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Watching comedy double acts and laughing loudly relieves my stress.
examples.ja: 漫才を見て大声で笑うことはストレス解消になる。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>comic</kanji> <kanji>talent</kanji>! And not just one, but two comic talents, because this means a <vocabulary>comic dialogue</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>comedy double act</vocabulary>. 

More specifically, 漫才 refers to a double act that features a "funny man" (ボケ) and "straight man" (ツッコミ) in a comic dialogue routine. 漫才 is one of the most popular forms of comedy in Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: If I make a mistake in Japanese would you mind correcting it on the spot for me?
examples.ja: もし私の日本語に間違いがあれば、その場で訂正してもらってもいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>revise</kanji> something to make it <kanji>correct</kanji> you are doing a <vocabulary>correction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>revision</vocabulary>.

訂正 refers to officially correcting mistakes in written or spoken content, like documents, reports, or statements. It can describe both the act of correcting and the correction itself.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If the bus schedule was revised, I need the revised edition.
examples.ja: バスの時刻が改訂されたなら、改訂版の時刻表をもらわなきゃ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>renew</kanji>ed and <kanji>revise</kanji>d <kanji>edition</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>revised edition</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: The Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy plans to hold a meeting on the same day.
examples.ja: その日は経済財政諮問会議が開催される予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: I need to <kanji>consult</kanji> you on this <kanji>problem</kanji>, if I could. I have a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary> I'd like to ask you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We need to discuss this problem at the board of directors meeting.
examples.ja: この問題は取締役会に諮る必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>consult</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to consult with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to discuss</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to consult with</vocabulary> a <reading>hacker</reading> (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.

examples.en: We were deeply impressed by his piano performance.
examples.ja: 私達は彼のピアノの演奏に深く感銘を受けました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>inscription</kanji> is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very <vocabulary>deep impression</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How much longer will it take you to decide which brand to recommend to your customer?
examples.ja: 後どれくらいでお客さんに推奨する銘柄が決まりそうですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>inscription</kanji>'s <kanji>pattern</kanji> shows what <vocabulary>brand</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>make</vocabulary> this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!

examples.en: Each member of my family has this photo.
examples.ja: うちの家族の銘々がその写真を持っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You look at this <kanji>inscription</kanji> then you look at that <kanji>inscription</kanji> and you notice that <vocabulary>each</vocabulary> one is an <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary> inscription.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: One day, my son suddenly started speaking Japanese fluently, as if a dam in him had been broken.
examples.ja: 私の息子は、ある日突然、堰を切ったように日本語をペラペラ話し始めたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The village head decided to bury a human sacrifice in the embankment to prevent it from collapsing.
examples.ja: 村長は、堤が切れるのを防ぐため、堤に人柱を埋めることを決意しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary> that's made purely from bundles and packages. These <reading>包み</reading>(つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!

examples.en: The water is almost running over the embankment, so you should be careful.
examples.ja: 水が堤防を越えそうになっているから、近づかない方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>embankment</kanji> <kanji>prevent</kanji>s the water from going over the edge. It's an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was awakened by the smell of delicious miso soup in the air.
examples.ja: 美味しいみそ汁の匂いが漂ってきて、目が覚めました。

examples.en: Don't you think some tragic feeling is drifting from Mr. Asada, today?
examples.ja: 今日、浅田さんからなんかヤバイ悲壮感漂ってない？

examples.en: Farts after eating roasted sweet potatoes seem to hang in the air longer than normal farts.
examples.ja: 焼き芋を食べた後のおならは、他のおならよりも長い間空気中を漂う気がするよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to waft</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You're going <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary> away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "<reading>ta-da yo</reading>-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.

examples.en: When the mast broke and my yacht started drifting out to sea, I got a little pessimistic.
examples.ja: 帆が折れて、ヨットが海に漂流し始めた時は、ちょっと悲観的でしたね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drifting</kanji> down the <kanji>stream</kanji>. Something that is doing this is <vocabulary>drifting</vocabulary>. It could also be the <vocabulary>drift</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Imagine a wounded baby whale drifting ashore onto a sandy beach.
examples.ja: 傷ついた赤ちゃん鯨が、とある砂浜に漂着するところを想像してみてください。

meaning_mnemonic: Something has <kanji>drift</kanji>ed to the point where it has <kanji>arrive</kanji>d. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word <vocabulary>drifting ashore</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I swear, I will absolutely not change my mind about this marriage.
examples.ja: この結婚について、絶対に翻意することがないことを誓います。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>flip</kanji> your <kanji>idea</kanji> of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is <vocabulary>change one's mind</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was just looking over your translation.
examples.ja: ちょうど君の翻訳を見させてもらってたところだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Flip</kanji> the <kanji>translation</kanji> of a word from one language to another. That is the <vocabulary>translation</vocabulary> of that word (or phrase, etc.).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I know her skirt billowed in the wind, but rendering how he felt at the time is too difficult.
examples.ja: 彼女のスカートが風で翻ったのは分かるんですが、その時の彼の心象を翻訳するのは私には難しすぎます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means <kanji>flip</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean <vocabulary>to suddenly change</vocabulary> your mind, or your attitude, etc.
reading_mnemonic: For something <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, you'll need to ask the <reading>here guy</reading> (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.

examples.en: In this video, we will trace the trajectory of WaniKani from its birth until the present.
examples.ja: このビデオでは、ワニカニ誕生からこれまでの軌跡をたどります。

examples.en: A swarm of fireflies was flying above the rice fields, leaving beautiful trails of light.
examples.ja: 田んぼの上を、蛍の群れが美しい光の軌跡を描いて飛んでいた。

examples.en: When a car turns, the trajectories of the front wheels and rear wheels are different. As a result, there are cases where even if the front wheels avoid a collision, the rear wheels may still collide, leading to an accident.
examples.ja: 車が曲がる時、前輪と後輪では軌跡が違います。これによって、前輪にはぶつからなくても、後輪に巻き込まれて事故になるケースがあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Rut</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> left in the road are <vocabulary>track</vocabulary>s that mark the <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary> of a vehicle’s wheels.

This can also be used figuratively to refer to leaving or following some sort of trace, or to describe someone’s or something’s trajectory, among other things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Everyone was delighted to hear the news that the rocket entered orbit.
examples.ja: ロケットが軌道に入ったというニュースを聞いて、誰もが喜びました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rut</kanji> in the <kanji>road</kanji> is for some reason an <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary>. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary> that will send you into <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary>. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He accidentally killed his mother, the Japanese Empress.
examples.ja: 彼は誤って皇后であった母親を殺害してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>emperor</kanji> <kanji>empress</kanji> is the emperor's wife. That's the <vocabulary>Japanese Empress</vocabulary>, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: Every time I ignore a stop sign I get excited.
examples.ja: 止まれの標識を無視する度に、興奮するんです。

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>interest</kanji> is <kanji>stirred up</kanji>! I'm feeling <vocabulary>excitement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stimulation</vocabulary> from all this stirring up, in fact!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to <reading>こう</reading>いち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

examples.en: Her one word roused him to study for the test.
examples.ja: 彼女の一言が、彼を奮起させ、受験勉強をさせた。

meaning_mnemonic:
I'm getting all <kanji>stirred up</kanji>, which has caused me to <kanji>wake up</kanji> (figuratively). I'm <vocabulary>rousing</vocabulary> myself to tackle this challenge!

奮起 is a formal word for <vocabulary>rousing someone</vocabulary> or oneself to action in challenging situations. It describes a moment when someone decides to gather their strength and face a task or problem head-on.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Many people think that Koichi would name his first restaurant Tofugutei.
examples.ja: 多くの人が、コウイチは最初のレストランを「トーフグ亭」と名付けるのではないかと踏んでいる。

meaning_mnemonic: If you see the kanji <kanji>restaurant</kanji> attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a <vocabulary>restaurant</vocabulary>, especially a <vocabulary>traditional Japanese restaurant</vocabulary>. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary>s, those traditional <vocabulary>pavilion</vocabulary>s you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I was told by various people that if I looked to him for guidance it could be trusted, but that was clearly a mistake.
examples.ja: 色んな人から、彼の指導を仰げば間違いないと言われましたが、それは明らかに間違いでした。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>look up to</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to look up at</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to look up to</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Personally, I look up to the color <reading>青</reading> (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.

examples.en: I hate people who use pompous wording.
examples.ja: 仰々しい言葉遣いをする人は嫌いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Someone tries to make you <kanji>look up to</kanji> them... twice. That's too many times to look up to someone. When this happens, this person must be <vocabulary>pompous</vocabulary>.

仰々しい is a relatively formal word often used to describe something that feels <vocabulary>exaggerated</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>excessively grand</vocabulary>. It can refer to a speech, ceremony, or behavior that comes across as overly formal, showy, or dramatic.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.

examples.en: I was astonished at how quickly Mami could eat bacon.
examples.ja: 私は真美がどれだけ速くベーコンを食べれるのかってことにびっくり仰天しました。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>look up to</kanji> <kanji>heaven</kanji>, and I am <vocabulary>taken aback</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amazed</vocabulary> by it. It's just so amazing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I believe in Christianity and I have unwavering faith in God.
examples.ja: 私はキリスト教を信仰していて、神への揺るぎない思いを持っています。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>believe</kanji> and <kanji>look up to</kanji> a higher power, for I have <vocabulary>religious faith</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is <reading>こう</reading>いち.

examples.en: How about giving Fugu the title of an earl, and calling him Count Fugu?
examples.ja: フグの爵位を伯爵にして、フグ伯って呼ぶことにするのはどうかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>chief</kanji> of this district is that guy, the <vocabulary>count</vocabulary>. He's also the <vocabulary>earl</vocabulary> of another district, and the <vocabulary>chief</vocabulary> of yet another.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I wonder why my aunt didn’t come to our wedding ceremony.
examples.ja: 伯母はどうして私達の結婚式に来ようとしなかったんだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: Who is the <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>mother</kanji>? That's your <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary>. And this aunt is the older sister of your mom or dad because she is the chief mother. An aunt who is a younger sister of your parent is 叔母, which is another word for "aunt" you already know!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all.

examples.en: I strain my back every once in a while.
examples.ja: 偶にぎっくり腰になるんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while. Also note that this word is usually written in hiragana. You'll only occasionally see it in kanji.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Occasionally</vocabulary> <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the local ball girl, will take a break from her duties. But it's really only once in a while, because Tamara is such a hard worker.

examples.en: I couldn't help but laugh at the coincidence.
examples.ja: 偶然の一致に思わず笑ってしまった。

examples.en: It was an accidental shot, but it turned out to be a good photo.
examples.ja: 偶然なショットだけど、いい写真が撮れた。

examples.en: I unexpectedly ran into a friend from high school at the airport.
examples.ja: 空港で偶然、高校時代の友人に会ったんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that happened <kanji>accidentally</kanji> by <kanji>nature</kanji> probably happened <vocabulary>by chance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unexpectedly</vocabulary>. It was just a <vocabulary>coincidence</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve been thinking about looking for a new spouse.
examples.ja: 新しい配偶者を探そうかとずっと考えているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Distribute</kanji> yourself <kanji>accidentally</kanji> to <kanji>someone</kanji>. That person ended up becoming your <vocabulary>spouse</vocabulary>. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The dirty water didn’t stop her swimming in the Yodogawa.
examples.ja: 汚い水にも怯まず、彼女は淀川で泳いだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>eddy</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about <vocabulary>Yodogawa</vocabulary>. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.

examples.en: The number of people visiting the ancient tomb has been increasing in recent years.
examples.ja: 近年その古墳を訪れる人が増えています。

examples.en: In this cafe, you can eat cakes in the shape of ancient tombs.
examples.ja: このカフェでは、古墳の形をしたケーキが食べれます。

examples.en: Furukawa-kun is ancient tomb enthusiast.
examples.ja: 古川君は、古墳マニアなんですよ。

examples.en: The Kofun period refers to the period from around the end of the 3rd century to the 7th century.
examples.ja: 古墳時代は、三世紀末頃から七世紀頃までの時代を言います。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>tomb</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ancient tomb</vocabulary>. They're mostly from the <vocabulary>Kofun</vocabulary> period, and indeed that's where the period gets its name.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You should definitely visit the tomb of Tutankhamen.
examples.ja: ツタンカーメンの墳墓は絶対に訪れた方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tomb</kanji> <kanji>grave</kanji> is a <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>... or it could be a <vocabulary>tomb</vocabulary>. Or maybe both.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is such a magnificent song. I’m so impressed.
examples.ja: なんて壮大な曲なんだ。凄く感動しています。

meaning_mnemonic: It's so <kanji>robust</kanji> and <kanji>big</kanji>! Things like this are <vocabulary>magnificent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>grand</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>epic</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: His older brother had a heart attack and passed away in the prime of life.
examples.ja: 彼のお兄さんは壮年期に心臓発作を起こして亡くなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>robust</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are the best years of your life! This is the <vocabulary>prime of life</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are planning a farewell party for him on Friday. Are you available?
examples.ja: 彼のために金曜日壮行会を予定してるんですが、ご都合は如何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
You want to make someone feel <kanji>robust</kanji> when they <kanji>go</kanji> away somewhere, so you give them a <vocabulary>send-off</vocabulary>. It's just a nice way to say <vocabulary>farewell</vocabulary>!

壮行 is usually for celebratory send-offs and appears in words like 壮行会 (farewell party) or 壮行式 (pep rally).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Wow! A bunch of spinach is only ninety-eight yen!
examples.ja: わっ！ほうれん草一把で九十八円だって。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji refers to a <kanji>bundle</kanji>, but this refers to a <vocabulary>counter for bundles</vocabulary>. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!
reading_mnemonic: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ)!

examples.en: Honestly, I haven’t even been able to grasp the overall situation yet.
examples.ja: 正直、まだ事態の把握すら出来ていない状況です。

meaning_mnemonic: Using the <kanji>grasp</kanji> meaning of 把 and combining it with <kanji>grip</kanji>, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean <vocabulary>grasp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>understand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is a mini elevator used to transport food and other small things in this restaurant.
examples.ja: このレストランには、食事やその他の細々したものを運搬するためのミニエレベータがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>carry</kanji> you and <kanji>transport</kanji> you. That's a form of <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary>. Could also be a <vocabulary>carriage</vocabulary>, which is also a form of transport.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I dislocated my left shoulder when I was doing conveyance work.
examples.ja: 搬送作業時に左肩を脱臼してしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that <kanji>transport</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> you places are forms of <vocabulary>transportation</vocabulary>.

搬送 is most often used in medical contexts to refer to the transportation of patients.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: By 7pm on Sunday, we need to take out all of our work pieces.
examples.ja: 日曜の夜七時までに全ての作品を搬出する必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Transport</kanji> and <kanji>exit</kanji> these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to <vocabulary>carry out</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The eerie cave stood silently on the village's northern outskirts.
examples.ja: その薄気味悪い洞は、村の北外れにひっそりとたたずんでいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Hoe Ra</reading> (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

examples.en: A polar bear was snoozing in the hollow of a tree and a lumberjack soon came along.
examples.ja: 白熊が木の空洞の中でうたた寝をしていると、近くに木こりがやって来ました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>cave</kanji> is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a <vocabulary>hollow</vocabulary>, but can also refer to a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I stumbled in the cave and sprained my ankle.
examples.ja: その洞穴でつまずいて、足首を捻挫しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cave</kanji> <kanji>hole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>den</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary>, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?

examples.en: I don’t want to stay single my whole life.
examples.ja: 生涯ずっと独身なんて嫌だよう。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>life</kanji> <kanji>horizon</kanji> is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is <vocabulary>one's lifetime</vocabulary>, though it could also refer to <vocabulary>one's career</vocabulary>. Basically, at the end of it something dies.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Australia’s quarantine laws are very strict, so you shouldn’t take any food there.
examples.ja: オーストラリアの検疫法はすっごく厳しいから、食べ物は何も持って行かない方が身のためだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: We have to <kanji>examine</kanji> you during this <kanji>epidemic</kanji>... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a <vocabulary>quarantine</vocabulary>, sorry about that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I went to the doctor because I always have a slight fever and terrible headache, and I was told that my immune system is weakening.
examples.ja: いつも微熱とひどい頭痛があるのでお医者さんに行ったら、免疫機能が弱ってきていると言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>excuse</kanji> yourself from the <kanji>epidemic</kanji>, you'll have to have <vocabulary>immunity</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immunization</vocabulary> from the disease.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Everyone in that village died from the plague.
examples.ja: その村の人々は、全員疫病で亡くなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>epidemic</kanji> of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is going to come from an <vocabulary>infectious disease</vocabulary>. Perhaps a <vocabulary>plague</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>epidemic</vocabulary> of some kind?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That teacher was fired because he threatened some male students with a knife.
examples.ja: その教師は何名かの男子生徒を刃物で脅したとして解雇されました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>threaten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: I'm going <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary> you with your life if you have a bad <reading>odo</reading>r (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

examples.en: My heart aches whenever I see the pictures of those starving children.
examples.ja: 飢えに苦しむ子どもたちの写真を見る度に胸が痛みます。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is <vocabulary>hunger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>starvation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 飢える.

examples.en: "Can you do this by tomorrow?" "I see, I’ll give it my best."
examples.ja: 「これ、明日までにできるかな？」「わかりました。最善を尽くします。」

examples.en: We ate up all the emergency food stocks.
examples.ja: 食料の備蓄を食べ尽くしてしまった。

examples.en: Viet knows everything about the yakuza world.
examples.ja: ビエトはヤクザ界のことを知り尽くしている。

meaning_mnemonic: 尽きる is "to be exhausted". 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it <vocabulary>to exhaust something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to devote oneself</vocabulary> to a certain cause.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 尽きる.

examples.en: I didn’t like my dad’s bento because he never really took coloring into account and all of it was brown.
examples.ja: 父の弁当は、彩りについて全く考慮がされておらず、全部茶色だったので嫌でしたね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: <vocabulary>coloring</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an <reading>色 do</reading>g, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.

examples.en: Whenever I wake up with a pounding headache, I lament drinking too much the night before.
examples.ja: ガンガン響く頭と共に目を覚ます度に、前日の夜飲み過ぎたことを悔やみます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>regret</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to regret</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mourn</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 悔しい.

examples.en: My man is in the middle of the fist fight in the club.
examples.ja: 俺の連れは今クラブで殴り合いの喧嘩の真っ最中さ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got <vocabulary>punches</vocabulary> that have <vocabulary>come together</vocabulary> with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a <vocabulary>fistfight</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.

examples.en: We had an early lunch before the raid.
examples.ja: 殴り込みの前に早めの昼食を取りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Punch</kanji> your way <kanji>into</kanji> a place, and you're launching a <vocabulary>raid</vocabulary>. 

殴り込み usually means a raid by gang members or delinquents, where they barge into someone's home or enemy territory to start a fight.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 殴る and the kanji 込.

examples.en: Don’t give up! Accomplish it! You can do it!
examples.ja: 諦めないで！やり遂げるんだ！お前なら出来るよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accomplish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to accomplish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky <reading>toe</reading> (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.

examples.en: I like clothes made of hemp cloth, but they’re rather expensive.
examples.ja: 麻布の服が好きなんだけど、結構お値段が高いんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hemp</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hemp cloth</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

examples.en: My uncle's been home feeling melancholy.
examples.ja: 伯父は、鬱気で家でふさぎ込んでいる。

examples.en: This song can really blow the gloom away.
examples.ja: 鬱気を吹き飛ばしてくれるような歌ですね。

examples.en: My depression's bothering me today and I can't get myself to study Japanese.
examples.ja: 今日は鬱気が邪魔をして、日本語を勉強する気になれません。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>gloomy</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> has filled the room. This puts you in a <vocabulary>gloomy mood</vocabulary>. You are now <vocabulary>feeling downcast</vocabulary>.

This word is formal, so you'll mostly just see it in literature.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

examples.en: My uncle is a banker.
examples.ja: 伯父は銀行員です。

meaning_mnemonic: Who is the <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji>? That's your <vocabulary>uncle</vocabulary>. And this uncle is the older brother of your mom or dad because he is the chief father. An uncle who is a younger brother of your parent is 叔父, which is another word for "uncle" you already know!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all.

examples.en: I can see light burning in that room.
examples.ja: あの部屋に明かりが灯るのを見たんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lamp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who wanted the candle <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>? <reading>Tom</reading> (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.

examples.en: The children laughed innocently.
examples.ja: 子供達は無邪気に笑い合っていた。

meaning_mnemonic: If there is <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>wicked</kanji> about your <kanji>spirit</kanji> at all, you are a going to be an <vocabulary>innocent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>simple minded</vocabulary> person.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Are the beans cooked well?
examples.ja: 豆、ちゃんと煮えてる？

examples.en: Well, it's about time that the potatoes should be cooked through.
examples.ja: さて、そろそろジャガ芋が煮えるころだ。

examples.en: There was a mysterious soup gurgling and boiling in the pot.
examples.ja: 鍋の中には怪しげなスープがグツグツと煮えていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

You already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be boiled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!
